keyTakeAways: A major road collision occurred on the Kampala-Gulu Highway in Uganda, resulting in 63 fatalities.
The accident was caused by two buses overtaking a truck and car from opposite directions, leading to a head-on collision.
All 63 dead were occupants of the involved vehicles, with no survivors.
The Kampala-Gulu Highway is one of Uganda's busiest roads, linking the capital to northern Uganda, increasing traffic volume and risk.
At least some of the victims were injured, with survivors taken to Kiryandongo Hospital and other medical centers.
The incident has raised serious concerns about road safety and dangerous overtaking behavior in Uganda.
Road fatalities in Uganda have been rising: 5,144 deaths in 2024, up from 4,806 in 2023 and 4,534 in 2022.
Irene Nakasiita, a Red Cross spokeswoman, described the aftermath as 'gruesome' and emphasized the scale of the tragedy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly head-on collision on the Kampala-Gulu Highway in Uganda resulted in 63 deaths, caused by two buses attempting to overtake a truck and car from opposite directions. The incident, which occurred just after midnight, underscores the growing danger of reckless overtaking on one of the country’s busiest roads. The death toll is part of a rising trend in road fatalities—rising from 4,534 in 2022 to 5,144 in 2024—prompting authorities to issue urgent warnings. Injured individuals were taken to hospitals such as Kiryandongo, and Red Cross officials described the aftermath as extremely traumatic, emphasizing the need for improved road safety measures and driver behavior regulation.
title: Collision on highway near Uganda’s capital kills 63 people
